instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No chime
threads.message:
Already fix 5v rail replaced <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. 
Turn on but no chime
I get light on the mouse

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU_S0</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> - 1.0v

I think CPU is dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No chime
threads.message:
I think you need to get another mouse. No way it can have a light if there is no CPU Vcore.

Voltage on <RESISTOR>R7160</RESISTOR>? How does <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No chime
threads.message: 5V rail went high and killed a bunch of crap. <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> probably dead too, pile of shit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No chime
threads.message:
Similar problem on this board. But on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> my voltages are different. Already swapped <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. Nothing abnormally hot.

Pin 1: 3,3v
Pin 2: 5mv
Pin 3: 0.4mv
